on default ',' but if you need to use a comma in a value you want to display, feel free to change

this is a lot of code and even with comments it's difficult to put together what everything does, so look for these pink comments for a tl;dr
the groups are labelled with what level of flexibility they have for developers, but it is worth looking through everything for clarity.

events.title: ui / init
events.description: everything to do with setting properties when something is created, you can find On Created events for most UI families here

events.title: ui / sections
events.description: a few essential functions you'll need for enabling and disabling sections, which can be thought of as a collection of UI components - you can set an object's section with the instance variable.

children.text:
you can think of sections like a collection of buttons. 

on a main menu layout alone you'll probably have multiple sections, such as...

- a 'main' section, which would include buttons with an id like mainPlay, mainSettings, mainQuit, etc.
- a 'mainPlay' section, where upon clicking the mainPlay button, new options appear such as mainPlayNewGame, mainPlayLoadGame, etc.
- a 'mainQuit' section, where clicking mainQuit takes you to mainQuitConfirm and mainQuitCancel
- even more sections like 'mainSettings', which could lead to 'mainSectionsVideo', 'mainSectionGameplay', 'mainSectionControlsKeyboardConfirmBind', who knows!

so long as it's part of the ui family, you should assign a section to it

below are some functions you should use to enable and disable sections. some examples of using these functions are...

- on start of layout, enable section "main"
- on 'mainPlay' selected, disable section "main" and enable section "mainPlay"
- on clicking 'mainPlayNewGame', maybe a transition will happen and fade to a new layout. to make sure no more buttons can be pressed, disable all sections
enable/disable a UI section - this will run a ui update

children.functionDescription: enables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables every UI component on the layout - runs a UI update

actions.text: set navigation mode to default, then call a ui update

events.title: ui / behavior
events.description: the hardest to understand group in this entire framework, for sure. there are some things here that you will want to change, like the custom actions for UI components that define the default behavior of every component when certain events happen. there's also stuff to do with updates, selection, and navigation.

children.text: some functions here are marked with [INTERNAL], meaning that you shouldn't be using them when making your game unless it's for a specific case where you know what you're doing

children.title: ui / behavior / custom actions
children.description: custom actions are a modular way to apply visual behavior like tweening to all objects in the UI families, but also override the behavior for individual objects

children.text:
with these custom actions, you can provide a default behavior here, and override the default by creating an override custom action for the button object.

for example, right now it's set so that when you chose a button it grows, and unchoosing it makes it shrink again.

if you want a special button type on some layout to instead become brighter, you can make an override by creating a new custom action for that object, and calling the action "uiChoose" exactly.
you'll know you've done it right because it'll say 'Overridden' next to it. if it has any parameters, copy those over too.

lastly, if you wanted to do the default behavior but THEN ALSO do something custom, then you can call the family custom action as part of the overwrite to turn it into an extension.
if that didn't make sense, it's a little complicated to explain here, so see link below.

to learn more about custom actions and overriding, see here --> https://www.construct.net/en/make-games/manuals/construct-3/project-primitives/events/custom-actions

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text: fade in when this component's section is activated

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text: fade out a little when this component's section is deactivated

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text: make the component grow when chosen (mouseover, highlight, whatever you want to call it)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text: make the component shrink when no longer chosen

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
keep in mind you shouldn't use this custom action when making events for when a button is clicked... this is intended for animations/sounds only.
for actually doing something when a specific button gets clicked, see the comment on the function 'uiSelect [INTERNAL]'
little tilt effect

children.text:
when overriding this custom action, the conditions don't carry to your override.

these custom actions exist on the uiSliderHandle family, but we tie it to the relevant ui family object with a UID check and perform changes there to access the tween behavior and size variables (which are not required)

here, I pass off the rest of the move handler to another custom action which simply updates position. 

the reason uiSliderHandleMove and uiSliderHandleUpdatePosition are different is because you may want to update the slider's position without necessarily triggering the animation where you move the handle, such as when manually updating a slider's properties

the tween here is pretty specific about what it wants to do - it uses lerp to find the right position to go to.
if you want to override this action without calling this default, then take note of the expression used here so you can get the right slider position.

children.title: ui / behavior / components
children.description: the inner-workings of components such as sliders, scroll views, and checkboxes. normally you shouldn't have to edit these, if you want to change animations check 'ui / behavior / custom actions'

children.text: not all components need additional internal programming, like checkboxes. only the ones that do can be found here.

children.title: ui / behavior / components / misc
children.description: stuff related to all components, essentials like the UID-to-ID conversion functions

children.text: given an ID, retrieve a UID

children.functionDescription: given an ID, retrieve a UID

functionParameters.name: ID
functionParameters.comment: id that you can find on the ui family

actions.text:
the reason this function is important is due to the family overlap that exists throughout this framework - almost all UI components exist in the 'ui' family, but some exist in other ui-related families.

of course, for example, you can't pick a 'uiSliderHandle' from a 'ui' id... but you can always pick it if you have the UID!

children.title: ui / behavior / components / slider / handle
children.description: this can get complicated, so just remember that the handle is different from the bar. you can only have one bar, but you can have multiple handles. as such, the value is stored in the handle itself and this is the part that can be navigated. also, slider handles can be designated as scroll handles, which can be used in a scroll view.

children.text: get the position of this handle, according to its value
these are more reliable than trying to get uiSliderHandle.X and .Y, since the position may be tweening

children.title: ui / behavior / navigate / slider
children.description: controlled by uiSetNavigationMode, disabled on start on purpose

children.text:
the math here is very specific
we take the sin() or cos() of the angle of the slider bar
then we take the sign() of it, which provides either -1, 0, or 1
finally depending on if its an increment or decrement we make it negative or positive

this allows increments to work even with irregular slider bar angles
center slider handle if scrollable

events.title: ui / interaction
events.description: an interface from which the player can actually navigate and use the game UI. you can find keyboard, mouse, and gamepad controls here, with some variables you can adjust as you see fit.

children.text:
this is where the user actually uses inputs to be able to interact with the ui. 
once again I don't recommend messing with any of this stuff...

but, if you want to change how fast it scrolls when you hold a directional button, you could change the constant variables below.
on default, you need to hold down a button for 0.5 seconds, before it starts auto scrolling every 0.1 seconds
how long you need to hold down an input in order to start the auto-choosing behavior
how often the input repeats when auto-choosing
if ui input was triggered on this frame (make sure this variable is above the events, won't work otherwise)
how often the input repeats when using gamepad to scroll
gamepad deadzone for UI navigation
what fraction of a step does the gamepad scroll per timer fire

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm
children.description: keyboard AND mouse controls found here - note that this group does get disabled when switching to gamepad.

children.text: if gamepad is detected, switch to gamepad controls

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm / mouse
children.description: the mouse controls for UI are fundamentally different from keyboard and gamepad, since it isn't directional. it's still a part of the 'kbm' group though since you can't use a mouse and a gamepad.

children.text: the reason carousel isn't present here is because mouse controls work differently for them. when you click a carousel, you don't enter a new navigation mode, you just increment or decrement it based on which side of the object you clicked. as a result, you can find carousel selection in the default group
mouseover choosing

iterate through all ui components that mouse is currently over, in order of zIndex
(not all components are eligible in cases like being off their canvas)
choose this component, but only if it's not already chosen
if set to center on mouseover, call the centering function
run a generic update
if not over any ui components that are active
left click to select option

actions.text: below you can find normal button selection, as well as an exception for carousels

children.text: if carousel
basically takes mouse position and rotates it relative to the carousel angle
increment
decrement
else just normal select
